title: Pear Tallow Balm: The Weird Winter Thing That Actually Worked
body:
Okay so my face hurts. Like, actually hurts. It’s that specific winter skin feeling where you walk from your car to your front door, which is maybe twenty steps, and the wind hits you and it’s not even that cold but your cheeks just go tight. And they stay that way. All evening. It feels like your skin shrank two sizes. You know that feeling? My hands are worse. They look like a topographic map of some sad, dry planet. I was washing a mug earlier and the skin near my thumb just split. No drama, just a little white line that stung when the soap got in. Winter skincare. It’s a whole thing.

I was scrolling on my phone one night, my neck hurt from the stupid chair, and I kept seeing this stuff. Tallow balm. Beef fat for your face. I mean, come on. It sounded like something my great-grandmother would have used before they invented, you know, actual lotion. But I was desperate. I’d tried the thick drugstore creams in the tubs that sit on top of your skin like a greasy mask. I’d tried the fancy French pharmacy stuff that costs as much as a decent takeout order. My skin would drink it up for an hour and then go back to being a desert. I was a lizard person. So I figured, why not. Weirdest thing I’ve ever bought online, probably. I got the Whipped Tallow Balm in Pear from this little Etsy shop. It’s made in France from grass-fed beef suet, whipped up. They say it mimics human skin oil so it sinks in deep. Sounded like marketing talk, but my split thumb was judging me.

## How Beef Fat Ended Up on My Nightstand

Look, I was skeptical. The whole concept is just… out there. You picture a jar of lard. But it arrived in this cute little jar, and when I opened it, the texture was nothing like I expected. It’s whipped, so it’s like this dense, kind of bouncy cream. You scoop a bit and it holds its shape. Then you warm it between your fingers and it just… melts. Into nothing. It doesn’t feel greasy. It feels like your skin ate it. That was the first surprise. The second was the smell. It’s Pear scented. I was braced for something medicinal or, I don’t know, meaty? But no. It’s just a soft, clean, fruity smell. Not like a candy pear. More like the idea of a pear. It’s there and then it’s gone in a second. My cat sniffed my hand and looked deeply unimpressed, which I took as a good sign.

My routine before was complicated. Serum, then moisturizer, then sometimes an oil, then maybe another cream if I was feeling extra crispy. It took forever. Now? I wash my face, pat it dry, and rub a tiny bit of this tallow balm between my palms and just press it all over. Face, neck, the backs of my hands. Done. It takes maybe twenty seconds. Sometimes I use it on my elbows and knees before bed if they’re looking particularly ashy. The weird science part, which I looked up after it started working, is that beef tallow is supposedly really close to the sebum our own skin makes. So instead of just sitting on top, it sort of tricks your skin into thinking it’s already hydrated? I don’t know. I’m not a chemist. All I know is it absorbs. Fast.

## What This Stuff Actually Does For Dry Winter Skin

The first week, I didn’t notice much. My skin felt… fine. Not worse. Not amazingly better. Just fine. Which was already an upgrade from “tight and painful.” But then I had to fly to see my family for the holidays. Plane air is the absolute worst. It sucks every molecule of moisture out of you. I brought my little jar of tallow balm in my carry-on. Slapped some on in the airport bathroom after security, which felt ridiculous, but whatever. The whole flight, my skin didn’t have that parched, papery feeling. When I got off the plane, my face didn’t feel like it needed an emergency intervention. That’s when I was like, oh. Huh.

The real test is my hands. I’m constantly washing them, using sanitizer, scraping ice off my car windshield. They are the battlefield. Since I’ve been using the tallow balm on them at night, those little splits and cracks haven’t come back. The skin is just… smoother. Not “baby soft” or any of that nonsense. It just doesn’t hurt anymore. It doesn’t catch on my sweater. I was making meatballs the other night and realized I wasn’t wincing when the salty mix hit my dry spots. It’s a small victory. But when you’ve been dealing with painful skin all season, it feels huge. Winter skincare doesn’t have to be a ten-step punishment. Sometimes it’s just one weird jar of whipped beef fat that works.

I keep it on my bedside table next to an old coaster and a hair tie. It’s just part of the landscape now. My partner asked what it was and I said “face cream” and he just nodded and didn’t ask further questions, which is probably for the best. Sometimes I’ll put it on and then scroll through my phone for too long and the light from the screen is the only light in the room and I’ll think about how strange it is that this is the thing that fixed my skin. Not the expensive stuff in the fancy packaging. This simple, kind of ancient ingredient. It’s humbling, in a way. Or maybe I’m just tired. Wait, where was I going with this.

## Would I Buy This Pear Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. I already did, actually. I’m maybe halfway through my first jar and I ordered a second one last week. Not because I’m worried about running out, but because my mom was visiting and her hands were so dry they were almost scaly. She’s skeptical of everything “natural” or “trendy,” but I made her try it. She put some on before bed, grudgingly. The next morning over coffee she was like, “What was that stuff?” in a tone that meant she wanted more. So I ordered her a jar. And one for me, because why not. It’s become my default for dry winter skin. For my face, my hands, any rough patch.

It’s not magic. It won’t make you look twenty years younger. But if your skin is feeling tight, angry, or just perpetually thirsty from the cold, dry air, this tallow balm just… helps. It feels like it helps your skin help itself, if that makes any sense. It’s simple. There’s no fragrance bomb, no tingling sensation, no promise of miracles. It’s just a rich, absorbing balm that does the one job you really need in winter: it keeps the moisture in. My skin barrier, or whatever people call it, feels repaired. I don’t get that wind-burn feeling as much. The little jar lasts forever because you need so little. Anyway. If you’re grappling with dry winter skin and nothing else is cutting it, this might be worth a weird shot. I got mine from a seller on Etsy, just search for Whipped Tallow Balm. The pear scent is nice. Light. Fresh. Doesn’t smell like dinner.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Seems to be, yeah. The idea is that it’s really similar to the oils our own skin produces. So it absorbs well and doesn’t just sit on top clogging pores. My face seems to think it’s good, anyway. No breakouts, just less dryness.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Hasn’t for me. And my skin can get fussy. Because it’s so similar to our skin’s sebum, it sort of gets recognized and absorbed instead of sitting there. It feels less pore-clogging than some of the thick silicone-based creams I’ve used.

**What does the Pear tallow balm smell like?**
It’s subtle. Really subtle. It’s a clean, fresh, slightly sweet fruity smell. Not like a pear candy or perfume. More like if you smelled a ripe pear from a few feet away. It fades almost immediately after you put it on. It’s just a nice little moment when you open the jar.

So yeah. That’s my unexpected winter skincare story. A jar of whipped tallow balm. My skin’s happy, I’m not in pain, and I don’t have a complicated routine. That’s a win for this season. If your skin’s being difficult, might be worth a look.
